metadata.case_name: Ahmedabad Millowners' Association v. Textile Labour Association
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 167 to 173, 537 and 538 of 1965

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellants (Ahmedabad Millowners Association and 67 employers) and respondent (Textile Labour Association) referred by Gujarat Government to Industrial Court Gujarat under section 73 of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, as dispute not likely to be settled by other means.

Dispute consists of three questions regarding payment of dearness allowance (DA) based on awards of Industrial Court Bombay dated 2nd March 1950 (as modified) read with award dated 27th April 1948, using Consumer Price Index (CPI) for Ahmedabad published by State Government since February 1964, Labour Bureau Simla series, and linking factor 3.17.

Industrial Court answered first question in favour of appellants, second and third in favour of respondent; directed payment of DA for March 1964 onwards using Simla series and linking factor 3.17 at 2.84 pies per day per point rise over pre-war 73; 75% of average DA of first six months 1959 (Rs. 63-15-9) consolidated with basic wage; effective from 1st January 1965, arrears by 30th April 1965.
Agreement between Fine Knitting Co. Ltd. and respondent; award applies only to spinning department, not hosiery.
History: Demand for DA post-WWII; arbitration Case No. 1 of 1940 by Industrial Court Bombay used 1926-27 budget inquiry, base index 73 (Aug 1939), neutralisation 66-2/3%.
Agreement 12 Aug 1941 raised DA by 45% from July 1941; award 15 Sep 1941 neutralised 96% over 73.
Petition No. 1 of 1943 by appellants for reduction rejected due to lack of data.
Award terminated post-WWII May 1945; respondent's Petition No. 1 of 1945 granted 3 months DA.
Notice of change 20 May 1945 by respondent for continuance till index above 73; award neutralised 76%, Rs. 4 for 11 points.
Revision Petition No. 1 of 1946 rejected full neutralisation.
Revision Petition No. 1 of 1947: 100% neutralisation for lowest paid, flat rate up to Rs. 150; 2.84 pies per point over 73.
Notice 31 Oct 1949 by appellants to terminate from 1 Jan 1950 due to crisis; respondent notice to continue; reference resulted in continuance per 1947 award.
Central Wage Board recommended 75% DA consolidation; joint application No. 1 of 1960, award consolidated Rs. 63-15-9 (75% avg first 6 months 1959).
Second Five Year Plan recommended new CPI surveys; Labour Bureau survey 1958-59 at Ahmedabad, base 1960=100.
Govt of India linking factor 2.98; Gujarat Expert Committee (Dr. Desai) recommended 3.17 and +19 points adjustment.
Gujarat accepted +19 points Nov 1963; Press Note 31 Jan 1964 continued old series; 29 Feb 1964 accepted 3.17, discontinued old series from Jan 1964.
Appellants paid under protest Jan 1964; 30 Mar 1964 resolved to pay on Dec 1963 index till resumption.
Respondent letter 3 Apr 1964 urged payment per new; led to reference.
Appellants' preliminary objection before Industrial Court: reference invalid without s.42 notice; rejected.
Industrial Court rejected appellants' claims on survey reliability, linking factor, paying capacity.
Appellants examined experts Gokhale and Chokshi; respondent disputed with charts.
Family living survey 1958-59: 722 families Schedule A, interview method, sample size based on 2% error margin.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants bound to pay DA on CPI since Feb 1964 using Labour Bureau Simla series and linking factor 3.17.
Whether appellants should pay DA treating State CPI since Feb 1964 as old 1926-27 series.
If not as above, how DA should be paid on State CPI since Feb 1964.
Validity of reference under s.73 without s.42 notice of change.
Reliability of 1958-59 Labour Bureau survey (sample size, interview method).
Appellants' paying capacity to bear additional DA burden.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference invalid under s.73 without s.42 notice as dispute concerns change in wages/DA (Sch II Entry 9).
1958-59 survey unreliable: inadequate sample size (<0.5% universe), unscientific interview method.
Linking factor 3.17 unscientific; devise new DA scheme on consolidated basic wage with 1960=100 base, or watch prices 2-3 years for average linking.
Additional burden beyond paying capacity; industry in crisis.

respondent_arguments.text: Reference valid under s.73; s.42 inapplicable to govt reference.
Survey scientific, under expert committee, follows ILO/UN standards; sample adequate for 2% error; interview method feasible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Expert opinions, Dr. Basu, Vasavada reply

respondent_arguments.text: Linking factor 3.17 approved by experts/Govts; flat DA unjust, flexible needed; new wage structure beyond reference.
Appellants' finances sound; no substantial deterioration warranting cut.

court_reasoning.text: S.73 non-obstante clause overrides s.42; reference valid if govt satisfied dispute not settleable otherwise; industrial dispute exists without notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power under s.73 for urgent cases like public peace/industry affect.

court_reasoning.text: Survey reliable: sample size adequate per modern stats (2% error), quality over quantity; interview method progressed, proper training.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 722 families ~1.4% working class families; follows ILO/UN.

court_reasoning.text: Linking factor 3.17 suitable arithmetical method, accepted by experts; old series obsolete; new scheme disrupts peace, beyond reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only one CPI now; flexible DA for justice.

court_reasoning.text: Paying capacity sound; no substantial deterioration for revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wage structure revisable if deterioration persists, but not here.

holdings.text: Reference under s.73 valid without s.42 notice.
1958-59 survey valid, no infirmity in sample/interview.
Use linking factor 3.17 with Simla series for DA.
No incapacity to pay; uphold Industrial Court directions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suryaprakash Weaving Factory v. The Industrial Court
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar view on s.73 reference validity without s.42.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reference of dispute, notice of change, definition of industrial dispute and wages; s.73 overrides for govt reference.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Industrial Court award directing appellants to pay DA using new CPI series from Labour Bureau Simla with linking factor 3.17 from March 1964, consolidating 75% prior DA, effective 1 Jan 1965 with arrears by 30 Apr 1965; rejects appellants' objections.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; confirms relief to respondent employees.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the State Government may, at any time, refer an industrial dispute to the arbitration of the Industrial Court..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Non-obstante clause validates reference without s.42.

key_quotes.text: The sample size for Ahmedabad was 720 families... The number of schedules finally collected and tabulated was 722 for Schedule A.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Industrial Court has found that... the textile industry of Ahmedabad is in a sound financial position.
key_quotes.speaker: court
